txt.en: 'Whatever magic the Snatcher had once used to conceal itself was undone.'
'The pallid creature I saw before me bore little resemblance to the Úbil of old, but I knew it could be no other.'
'Another child had been snatched. Úbil's wickedness could not go unanswered again.'
'Through my window, I saw the light of countless torches. Even women still in their bedgowns carried them.'
'Fearful of the light, the Snatcher screeched and sputtered as my people drove it out of Hultvís.'
Instance: The Snatcher
'But the Snatcher had claimed another life as it fled. Father was dead.'
'Úbil the Snatcher chased me into the darkness.'
'As if in answer, the Snatcher caught sight of my gaze.'
'It flew into a frenzy, shrieking and thrashing madly at whatever unseen spirit stood before it.'
'Úbil scrambled toward me with a hunger in its eyes.'
'Without a thought, I turned and ran.'
'I did not wait for Úbil to strike again. I ran as fast as I could.'
'When I learned what had happened, I ran to my father's side.'
'I trembled in the cold rain, but there was no turning back. Father had to be avenged!'
'His throat had been torn open... gnawed by the wicked jaws of the Snatcher.'
'No one saw me leave.'
'I embraced him and wept.'
'With father's dagger in my hand, I crept out of Hultvís into the woods.'
'In the pouring rain, I found the Snatcher's mud-slicked footprints.'
'The Snatcher wrapped its fingers around my neck, but all of a sudden, I heard a great roar!'
'With as much haste as I could muster, I followed them westward towards the cliffs overlooking the Anduin.'
'It was Beorn! Fearing the skin-changer's wrath, the Snatcher loosed its grip and fled cursing into the woods.'
'With my eyes shut, I felt the Snatcher's breath upon me.'
'As I ran, Úbil paused for a long time.'
Father
'My legs gave out beneath me as I ran. It was over, I thought. I shut my eyes.'
'That is all there is to tell.'
'DNT... To Part 2'
'At the woods' edge, I found Úbil the Snatcher.'
'A scream woke all of Hultvís. Úbil the Snatcher had returned.'
'In tales of old, it was said that Úbil had thin, black hair and often wore clothing it had stolen from the hól-budlan.'
